qas.question: What principles usually govern the Estonian orthography?
To how many phoneme's does each grapheme correspond?
What type of deviations are there from the single phoneme to each grapheme general principle?
On what occasions are š and ž replaced with sh and zh?

answers.text: Where it is very impractical or impossible to type š and ž

qas.question: What is an example of a word containing a voiceless glottal fricative?
What principles never govern the Estonian orthography?

plausible_answers.text: Where it is very impractical or impossible to type š and ž

qas.question: On what occasions are š and ž replaced with ch and zu?
What is an example of a word not containing a voiceless glottal fricative?
Foreign names are not considered what?

context: Although the Estonian orthography is generally guided by <a0_0><b5_0>ph<a1_0>one<a1_0/>mic principles<b5_0/><a0_0/>, with each grapheme corresponding to one phoneme, there are <a2_0>some historical and morphological deviations<a2_0/> from this: for example preservation of the morpheme in declension of the word (writing b, g, d in places where p, k, t is pronounced) and in the use of 'i' and 'j'.[clarification needed] <a3_0><b6_0>Where it is very impractical or impossible to type š and ž<b6_0/><a3_0/>, they are substituted with sh and zh in some written texts, although this is considered incorrect. Otherwise, the h in sh represents a <b8_0>voiceless glottal fricative<b8_0/>, as in <a4_0><b7_0>Pasha<b7_0/> (pas-ha)<a4_0/>; this also applies to some foreign names.
